We experimentally investigated the temperature dependence of the color rendering index (CRI) of a phosphor-conversion (PC) white light-emitting diode (LED) composed of a GaN-based blue LED chip and...
meta.name: twitter:description

meta.content: We experimentally investigated the temperature dependence of the color rendering index (CRI) of a phosphor-conversion (PC) white light-emitting diode (LED) composed of a GaN-based blue LED chip and yttrium aluminum garnet doped with Ce3+ (YAG) phosphor. For the 15 CRI values from R1 to R15, 12 CRI values were found to increase with temperature from 20 to 80 °C. The general CRI (Ra) was increased from 84.6 to 86.1 as the temperature increased from 20 to 80 °C. R9 which represents the color rendering property for the deep red was found to increase by more than 10% and some CRI values exhibited more than 20% increase in this temperature range. This increasing behavior of CRI with temperature is contrary to the case of a multi-chip-based white LED, where the Ra was reported to decrease with increasing temperature. The improvement in the CRI with temperature for the PC white LED is attributed to the relative increase of the spectral power distribution (SPD) in the wavelength range from 460 to 520 nm and the overall broadening of SPD with increasing temperature. As a result of the increase in the CRI with temperature, the PC white LEDs are expected to be advantageously used for stable high-temperature operation of LED lighting.
meta.name: citation_abstract

ul.li: Temperature dependence of the color rendering index of a phosphor-conversion white light-emitting diode

div.div:
We experimentally investigated the temperature dependence of the color rendering index (CRI) of a phosphor-conversion (PC) white light-emitting diode (LED) composed of a GaN-based blue LED chip and yttrium aluminum garnet doped with Ce
3+
(YAG) phosphor. For the 15 CRI values from
R
1
to
R
15
, 12 CRI values were found to increase with temperature from 20 to 80 °C. The general CRI (
R
a
) was increased from 84.6 to 86.1 as the temperature increased from 20 to 80 °C.
R
9
which represents the color rendering property for the deep red was found to increase by more than 10% and some CRI values exhibited more than 20% increase in this temperature range. This increasing behavior of CRI with temperature is contrary to the case of a multi-chip-based white LED, where the
R
a
was reported to decrease with increasing temperature. The improvement in the CRI with temperature for the PC white LED is attributed to the relative increase of the spectral power distribution (SPD) in the wavelength range from 460 to 520 nm and the overall broadening of SPD with increasing temperature. As a result of the increase in the CRI with temperature, the PC white LEDs are expected to be advantageously used for stable high-temperature operation of LED lighting.
I. INTRODUCTION
Section:

Recently, the use of white light sources based on semiconductor light-emitting diodes (LEDs) have considerably increased in the general lighting and display applications owing to the high efficiency and eco-friendliness.
1–3
1. P. Pust, P. J. Schmidt, and W. Schnick, Nat. Mater.
14
, 454 (2015).
https://doi.org/10.1038/nmat4270
2. J. Bhardwaj, J. M. Cesaratto, I. H. Wildeson, H. Choy, A. Tandon, W. A. Soer, P. J. Schmidt, B. Spinger, P. Deb, O. B. Shchekin, and W. Götz, Phys. Status Solidi A
214
, 1600826 (2017).
https://doi.org/10.1002/pssa.201600826
3. J. Cho, J. H. Park, J. K. Kim, and E. F. Schubert, Laser Photonics Rev
11
, 1600147 (2017).
https://doi.org/10.1002/lpor.201600147
The efficiency of white LEDs has been improved to a level that allows solid-state lighting to rapidly replace conventional lighting bulbs. There are basically two approaches for realizing white light sources using LEDs.
3–7
3. J. Cho, J. H. Park, J. K. Kim, and E. F. Schubert, Laser Photonics Rev
11
, 1600147 (2017).
https://doi.org/10.1002/lpor.201600147
4. L. Wang, R. J. Xie, T. Suehiro, T. Takeda, and N. Hirosaki, Chem Rev
118
, 1951 (2018).
https://doi.org/10.1021/acs.chemrev.7b00284
5. S. Muthu, F. J. P. Schuurmans, and M. D. Pashley, IEEE J. Sel. Top. Quantum Electron.
8
, 333 (2002).
https://doi.org/10.1109/2944.999188
6. E. F. Schubert and J. K. Kim, Science
308
, 1274 (2005).
https://doi.org/10.1126/science.1108712
7. M. H. Crawford, IEEE J. Sel. Top. Quantum Electron.
5
, 1028 (2009).
The first one is a multi-chip (MC) LED by combining three individual red, green, and blue LED chips. The second one is named as the phosphor-conversion (PC) white LED, which is composed of phosphors as down-converting luminescent materials and a blue or ultra-violet LED chip as a primary light source.

The luminous efficiency of a white light source is one of the key metric for energy savings considerations. The MC white LEDs are expected to exhibit high luminous efficiency because of no fundamental efficiency limit in LED chips. However, low internal quantum efficiency of InGaN materials in green wavelength region restricts practical application of MC white LEDs.
8–11
8. M. Peter, A. Laubsch, W. Bergbauer, T. Meyer, M. Sabathil, J. Baur, and B. Hahn, Phys. Status Solidi A
206
, 1125 (2009).
https://doi.org/10.1002/pssa.200880926
9. S. Saito, R. Hashimoto, J. Hwang, and S. Nunoue, Appl. Phys. Express
6
, 111004 (2013).
https://doi.org/10.7567/apex.6.111004
10. M. A. Maur, A. Pecchia, G. Penazzi, W. Rodrigues, and A. D. Carlo, Phys. Rev. Lett.
116
, 027401 (2016).
11. Y. H. Choi, G. H. Ryu, and H. Y. Ryu, Curr. Opt. Photon.
1
, 626 (2017).
https://doi.org/10.1103/physrevlett.116.027401
The PC white LEDs suffer from large Stokes’ shift loss. Nevertheless, they have become the mainstream in the LED market due to the simple structure, low cost, and relatively high luminous efficiency. Yttrium aluminum garnet (Y
3
Al
5
O
12
or YAG) doped with Ce
3+
(YAG:Ce) is the most widely employed phosphor material in PC white LEDs.

Besides the luminous efficiency, color rendering is an essential figure of merit for a light source used in illumination applications.
6
6. E. F. Schubert and J. K. Kim, Science
308
, 1274 (2005).
https://doi.org/10.1126/science.1108712
The color rendering index (CRI) is a measure of how true objects can be rendered by artificial light sources.
12
12. M. S. Rea and J. P. Freyssinier-Nova, Color Res. Appl.
33
, 192 (2008).
https://doi.org/10.1002/col.20399
For MC white LEDs, the CRI value can be increased by optimizing spectral distribution of each LED chip. However, it has been well known that there is a fundamental tradeoff between CRI and luminous efficacy of radiation.
13
13. A. Žukauskas, R. Vaicekauskas, F. Ivanauskas, R. Gaska, and M. S. Shur, Appl. Phys. Lett.
80
, 234 (2002).
https://doi.org/10.1063/1.1432107
For MC white LEDs with three or more LED chips can have a general CRI (
R
a
) of >80.
R
a
is the average of CRIs from
R
1
to
R
8
.
13,14
13. A. Žukauskas, R. Vaicekauskas, F. Ivanauskas, R. Gaska, and M. S. Shur, Appl. Phys. Lett.
80
, 234 (2002).
https://doi.org/10.1063/1.1432107
14. S. Chhajed, Y. Xi, Y. L. Li, Th. Gessmann, and E. F. Schubert, J. Appl. Phys.
97
, 054506 (2005).
https://doi.org/10.1063/1.1852073
PC white LEDs can also exhibit a high
R
a
of >80 as a result of broad spectral distribution and
R
a
can be increased by spectral optimization.
15–19
15. G. He and H. Yan, Opt. Express
19
, 2519 (2011).
https://doi.org/10.1364/oe.19.002519
16. A. Žukauskas, R. Vaicekauskas, F. Ivanauskas, H. Vaitkevičius, and M. S. Shur, Appl. Phys. Lett.
93
, 021109 (2008).
https://doi.org/10.1063/1.2955843
17. Y. Lin, Z. Deng, Z. Guo, Z. Liu, H. Lan, Y. Lu, and Y. Cao, Opt. Express
22
, A1029 (2014).
https://doi.org/10.1364/oe.22.0a1029
18. M. R. Krames, O. B. Shchekin, R. Mueller-Mach, G. O. Mueller, L. Zhou, G. Harbers, and M. G. Craford, J. Display Technol.
3
, 160 (2007).
https://doi.org/10.1109/jdt.2007.895339
19. G. He, J. Xu, and H. Yan, AIP Advances
1
, 032160 (2011).
https://doi.org/10.1063/1.3644342
However, PC white LEDs with YAG phosphors suffers from a low
R
9
value which represents the color rendering property for the deep red.
18,19
18. M. R. Krames, O. B. Shchekin, R. Mueller-Mach, G. O. Mueller, L. Zhou, G. Harbers, and M. G. Craford, J. Display Technol.
3
, 160 (2007).
https://doi.org/10.1109/jdt.2007.895339
19. G. He, J. Xu, and H. Yan, AIP Advances
1
, 032160 (2011).
https://doi.org/10.1063/1.3644342

In addition, the device temperature of LEDs may have a strong influence on the electrical and optical characteristics such as the emission power, operation voltage, the peak wavelength, and the spectral width.
6
6. E. F. Schubert and J. K. Kim, Science
308
, 1274 (2005).
https://doi.org/10.1126/science.1108712
As a result, the chromaticity point, correlated color temperature (CCT), CRI, and efficiency of LED-based light sources drift as the ambient temperature of the device increases. For a trichromatic LED-based MC white LED, it has been reported that the CCT increased from 6500 to 7200 K and the CRI decreased from 84 to 72 as the temperature increased from 20 to 80 °C.
14
14. S. Chhajed, Y. Xi, Y. L. Li, Th. Gessmann, and E. F. Schubert, J. Appl. Phys.
97
, 054506 (2005).
https://doi.org/10.1063/1.1852073
This large decrease in the CRI is attributed to the significant modification of spectral distribution from the optimum color condition with increasing temperature especially for a red LED. The decrease in CRI caused with increasing device temperature can be problematic for certain applications. However, there have been few studies on the temperature dependence of CRI for PC white LEDs.

In this paper, we report on the experimental investigation of the temperature-dependent CRI for the PC white LED with YAG phosphor. The spectral power distribution is measured as the temperature varies from 20 to 80 °C, and the temperature-dependent CRI values from
R
1
to
R
15
are obtained. It will be demonstrated that CRI values of the PC white LED increases with increasing temperature contrary to the case of MC white LEDs. The experimental results of temperature-dependent CRIs of the PC white LED are analyzed based on the temperature dependence of spectral power distribution.
II. EXPERIMENT
Section:

The white LED sample for experiments consisted of a blue LED chip and yellow-emitting YAG:Ce phosphor. The epi-wafer for fabricating the blue LED chip was grown on a c-plane sapphire substrate by metal-organic chemical vapor deposition. The LED epi-layer structures consisted of a Si-doped n-GaN layer, InGaN/GaN multiple-quantum-well active layers, and a Mg-doped p-GaN layer. The active layer structures were designed to emit blue light centered at 450 nm. Blue LED chips were fabricated as a vertical-injection type with dimensions 1×1 mm
2
. Then, the LED chip was mounted on a lead frame with dimensions of 8×8 mm
2
, and molded with transparent epoxy resin containing the YAG phosphor. The packaged white LED sample was soldered onto a metal printed circuit board (PCB) for good heat dissipation. The metal PCB was then mounted on a copper heat sink, and the temperature controlled by a thermoelectric cooler (TEC) system. The junction temperature rise for our LED package was measured to be only ∼12 K at 350 mA.

The optical and electrical characteristics of the fabricated PC white LED sample were measured using an LED characterization system with a calibrated integrating sphere. The LED sample was operated under pulsed current injection conditions with a pulse width of 1.0 ms and a duty cycle of 1% to minimize self-heating effects. The heat-sink temperature was controlled between 20 and 80 °C by the TEC system. Under this condition of the pulse width and duty cycle, the temperature rise can be negligible and hence the measured LED sample can be free from self-heating effects.
20–22
20. J. C. Zhang, Y. H. Zhu, T. Egawa, S. Sumiya, M. Miyoshi, and M. Tanaka, Appl. Phys. Lett.
92
, 191917 (2008).
https://doi.org/10.1063/1.2931698
21. D. S. Kim and B. Han, J. Appl. Phys.
119
, 125104 (2016).
https://doi.org/10.1063/1.4944800
22. Y. H. Choi, G. H. Ryu, and H. Y. Ryu, J. Korean Phys. Soc.
69
, 1286 (2016).
https://doi.org/10.3938/jkps.69.1286
The light output power and the spectral power distribution (SPD) were measured as the current increased to 350 mA. From the measured SPD, photometric and colorimetric quantities were calculated based on the procedure defined by CIE.
23,24
23. CIE publication, Method of Measuring and Specifying Color Rendering Properties of Light Sources, 13.3 (1995).
24. E. F. Schubert,
Light-Emitting Diodes
(
2nd edition
,
Cambridge University Press
,
New York
, 2006), Chapter 19 and 20.

Figure 1(a)
shows the SPD of the measured PC white LED sample at temperatures of 20, 40, 60, and 80 °C. The spectral data in
Fig. 1(a)
were measured at 350 mA. The SPD of the white LED sample shows two spectral peaks, each of which corresponds to the blue light leaked from the LED chip and yellow light emitted by the phosphor, respectively. The peak wavelength of blue light increases from 450 to 453 nm as the temperature increases from 20 to 80 °C, whereas that of yellow light remains at 555 nm, almost unchanged with temperature. The radiant power in both the blue and yellow spectral regions decreases with increasing temperature.
Figure 1(b)
shows temperature dependence of the luminous efficiency (LE) of the measured white LED sample. As the temperature increases from 20 to 80 °C, the peak LE, which occurs at ∼30 mA, decreases from 135 to 121 lm/W and the LE at 350 mA decreases from 98 to 89 lm/W. The decrease of LE with temperature can be attributed to the decrease in both the wall-plug efficiency of the blue LED chip and the conversion efficiency of YAG phosphor.

FIG. 1.
(a) Spectral power distribution (SPD) of the PC white LED sample at temperatures of 20, 40, 60, and 80 °C measured at 350 mA. (b) Luminous efficiency of the white LED sample as a function of injection current at temperatures of 20, 40, 60, and 80 °C.

Figure 2
shows the variation of the chromaticity coordinates in the CIE 1931
x-y
chromaticity diagram and the CCT with temperature for the PC white LED sample in
Fig. 1
. The chromaticity points moved from (0.324, 0.332) to (0.317, 0.324) as the temperature increased from 20 to 80 °C. The relative change of the chromaticity point was ∼2%. In this temperature range, the CCT increased from 5922 to 6302 K, corresponding to the relative change of ∼6%. This temperature-variation in the chromaticity coordinates and CCT of the measured PC white LED is about half of the MC white LED in Ref.
14
14. S. Chhajed, Y. Xi, Y. L. Li, Th. Gessmann, and E. F. Schubert, J. Appl. Phys.
97
, 054506 (2005).
https://doi.org/10.1063/1.1852073
, implying that PC white LEDs with YAG phosphor are more stable to the temperature change compared with MC white LEDs.

FIG. 2.
Variation of (a) chromaticity coordinates in the CIE 1931
x
-
y
chromaticity diagram and (b) CCT of the PC white LED sample as the temperature increased from 20 to 80 °C.
III. RESULTS AND DISCUSSION
Section:

Figure 3(a)
plots the CRI values from
R
1
to
R
8
as a function of temperature from 20 to 80 °C. As the temperature increases,
R
2
and
R
3
increase relatively rapidly. In particular,
R
3
increases from 84.3 to 91.8 as the temperature increases from 20 to 80 °C, corresponding to the relative increase of ∼8.5%. On the contrary,
R
7
and
R
8
decrease with temperature.
R
7
shows the largest decrease with temperature. However, the relative decrease of
R
7
is only ∼1.5% in the temperature range from 20 to 80 °C. Other CRI values do not exhibit appreciable temperature-dependence. The test color samples of
R
2
and
R
3
corresponds to the color of yellow and green, and those of
R
7
and
R
8
corresponds to the color of violet and purple. It will be shown that the spectral power of the yellow-green wavelengths increases with temperature, while that of the violet wavelengths decreases with increasing temperature. In
Fig. 3(b)
, the general CRI,
R
a
which is obtained by averaging CRIs from
R
1
to
R
8
, is plotted as a function of temperature.
R
a
increases slightly from 84.6 to 86.1 as the temperature increases from 20 to 80 °C. This thermally-stable
R
a
of a PC white LED is contrary to the case of a MC white LED, where the
R
a
was reported to decrease from 84 to 72 in the same temperature range.
14
14. S. Chhajed, Y. Xi, Y. L. Li, Th. Gessmann, and E. F. Schubert, J. Appl. Phys.
97
, 054506 (2005).
https://doi.org/10.1063/1.1852073

FIG. 3.
(a) CRI values of the measured PC white LED sample from
R
1
to
R
8
as a function of temperature from 20 to 80 °C. (b) General CRI (
R
a
) as a function of temperature from 20 to 80 °C.

Figure 4
plots the special CRI values from
R
9
to
R
15
as a function of temperature. All of special CRIs exhibit increasing behaviors with temperature from 20 to 80 °C. In particular,
R
10
increases rapidly from 59.5 to 71, corresponding to the relative increase of ∼18%. In addition, the low
R
9
value is improved from 30.2 to 33.5 with increasing temperature. Though
R
9
still remains low value at elevated temperature, the relative increase of
R
9
is more than 10% from 20 to 80 °C. Consequently, the general CRI and all special CRIs of a PC white LED with YAG phosphors are found to increase with increasing temperature, which is firstly demonstrated in our experiments.

FIG. 4.
Special CRI values of the measured PC white LED sample from
R
9
to
R
15
as a function of temperature from 20 to 80 °C.

In order to understand the results of the temperature-dependent CRI of the measured PC white LED quantitatively, the temperature dependence of the SPD was analyzed.
Figure 5(a)
shows the relative SPD of the PC white LED sample at temperatures of 20, 40, 60, and 80 °C. The relative SPD for each temperature was obtained by dividing the SPD in
Fig. 1(a)
by its peak spectral power around 450 nm. The SPD in the wavelength range from 460 to 520 nm is observed to increase as the temperature increases, which is attributed to the red shift of the blue LED spectrum and the broadening of the phosphor spectrum with increasing temperature. The increase of the spectral power in this wavelength region is believed to contribute to the overall increase of
R
a
and special CRIs with increasing temperature, especially for
R
2
,
R
3
, and
R
10
. On the contrary, the spectral power below 450 nm decreases slightly with increasing temperature due to the red shift of the blue LED spectrum, which resulted in the decrease of
R
7
and
R
8
with temperature.

FIG. 5.
(a) Relative spectral power distribution (SPD) of the PC white LED at temperatures of 20, 40, 60, and 80 °C measured at 350 mA. The relative SPD was obtained by normalizing the SPD to its peak spectral power for each temperature. (b) Relative standard deviation (RSD) of the SPD as a function of temperature. RSD is the ratio of the standard deviation to the mean of SPD.

It is widely accepted that a continuous and broad SPD across the visible wavelength region is a basic requirement on achieving a high CRI.
13,24–26
13. A. Žukauskas, R. Vaicekauskas, F. Ivanauskas, R. Gaska, and M. S. Shur, Appl. Phys. Lett.
80
, 234 (2002).
https://doi.org/10.1063/1.1432107
24. E. F. Schubert,
Light-Emitting Diodes
(
2nd edition
,
Cambridge University Press
,
New York
, 2006), Chapter 19 and 20.
25. R. Mirhosseini, M. F. Schubert, S. Chhajed, J. Cho, J. K. Kim, and E. F. Schubert, Opt. Express
17
, 10806 (2009).
https://doi.org/10.1364/oe.17.010806
26. P. C. Hung and J. Y. Tsao, J. Disp. Technol.
9
, 405 (2013).
https://doi.org/10.1109/jdt.2012.2224638
In PC white LEDs, the SPD becomes increasingly continuous and broaden with increasing temperature mainly because of the relative increase of SPD in the wavelength range from 460 to 520 nm. In addition, the fact that the thermal degradation of an InGaN blue LED chip and YAG phosphor is not so significant up to 80 °C is also believed to contribute to the temperature-stable CRI. In MC white LEDs, on the contrary, the SPD becomes less continuous with increasing temperature owing to the significant spectral red shift and degradation of an AlGaInP-based red LED. The SPD in the red component decreases substantially with increasing temperature, which resulted in the overall decrease of the CRI in MC white LEDs.

The temperature-dependent SPD is also analyzed statistically. The average and standard deviation of SPD was calculated for each temperature.
Figure 5(b)
shows the relative standard deviation (RSD), which is defined as the ratio of the standard deviation to the mean of SPD. The RSD will increase as the SPD becomes increasingly broaden. Therefore, the relation between RSD and the CRI is expected to have a positive correlation. The RSD of the SPD in
Fig. 5(a)
increases from 0.135 to 0.139 as the temperature increases from 20 to 80 °C. The relative increase of RSD is ∼2.5%. The increase of RSD with temperature implies that the spectral broadening contributed to the overall increase in the CRI of the PC white LED with increasing temperature.
IV. CONCLUSION
Section:

In this work, we investigated temperature dependence of the CRI of the PC white LED with YAG phosphor from 20 to 80 °C. Most of CRI values were found to increase with increasing temperature. As the temperature increased from 20 to 80 °C,
R
a
was increased from 84.6 to 86.1 and
R
9
was increased by more than 10%. In particular, a large increase in the CRI from 59.5 to 71 was observed for
R
10
in this temperature range. The improvement in the CRI with temperature is attributed to the relative increase of the SPD in the wavelength range from 460 to 520 nm and the overall broadening of SPD with increasing temperature. The increased CRI with temperature for the PC white LED is expected to be advantageously used for the stable high-temperature operation of LED light sources.

The authors are grateful to AMOLEDS, Inc., for their fabrication of the high-power ceramic LED packages used in this work. This work was supported by Nano Material Technology Development Program through the National Research Foundation of Korea (NRF) funded by the Ministry of Science, ICT & Future Planning (2015M3A7B7045490) and the Basic Science Research Program through the NRF of Korea funded by the Ministry of Education (2016R1D1A1B03932092).
